messages.subject: Akasaka Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: I have attached images of a recently acquired tsuba that I think my be 1st or 2nd Akasaka Tadamasa, as can be seen it has an ‘Owari’ look about it. the
messages.messageBody:
I have attached images of a recently acquired tsuba that I think my be 1st or 2nd Akasaka Tadamasa, as can be seen it has an �Owari� look about it. the edge has both linear grain and tekkotsu, very unusual. I am not too familiar with early Akasaka tsuba so any comments will be welcome.

Alan



--

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Fun isnt it! had a close look and no clear evidence of 3 layer construction (sorry) Its bugging me too. Having said that it screams quality (at least to me)and
messages.messageBody:
Fun isnt it!
had a close look and no clear evidence of 3 layer construction (sorry) Its bugging me too. Having said that it screams quality (at least to me)and looks absolutely great on a Daido katana for which I am attempting to put a together a koshirae . I started looking for Owari then this came up and I was very taken with it. After a lot of looking it still seems to fall between two camps, Owari or early Akasaka.
try not to loose any sleep thinking about it.
regards
paul

Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:
Paul,
Thanks for the photo. By round, I was picturing a rounded maru mimi, not a round cross section. A round cross section is not typical for early Akasaka guards. Later when the Akasaka were copying Higo work, they used their thinner style of round section rim. I don't think I've seen this kind of rim on an Akasaka piece, but I can't say it's impossible. They did some unusual things.

I'm not sure about your piece. The looseness of the sukashi design reminds me of early Akasaka, although the bird at the top is pretty thick for them. The iron surface shows more "modulation" that is typical for Akasaka. It looks more like something from the Owari region. The seppa dai is not far from Akasaka shape. The guard reminds me a little of a third generation piece that I have:

http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/akasaka.htm (second guard down from the top).

Looking inside the sukashi openings do you see any signs of three layer construction?

Tough one... it's bugging me already. Some Akasaka style, but a lot that is not. And I don't know what the "is not" part is. Thinking out loud...

Jim



Thanks Jim,
Yes I did intend to attach a photo, sorry I might get the hang of technology in another 30 or 40 years. I have put the image in the album (I think) under paulb. Please take a look and let me know if its there and what you think.
many thanks
paul

Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:
Paul,
A thick, round rim is typical for early Akasaka guards. Later ones tend to be thinner. The early Akasaka really favored a very "high," rounded rim compared with other groups working at the same time.

Sometimes tekkotsu are seen in early examples. Senkotsu is more common, which is a sort of long linear bone that forms where the inner and outer plates are joined.

I'm not sure if you intended there to be an attached photo. The list doesn't permit attachments, but you can post images in the group photo album at:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/

Log in and click on the "Photos" link at the left. I can provide detailed instructions for anyone who would like to learn how to post photos. It's quite easy.

Jim



Dear All,
I have been discussing the tsuba below with a number of friends from both this and another group. The concensus to date is that this is early Akasaka. While I am more than content with that attribution I was wondering how common the thick round mimi was in Aakasaka work? Also there are a lot of bones in the mimi. I understand that early Akasaka work was influenced by Owari tsuba, is this an example of this? or should I be looking in another direction.
All comments greatly appreciated.



---------------------------------

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Paul, Thanks for the photo.  By round, I was picturing a rounded maru mimi, not a round cross section.  A round cross section is not typical for early Akasaka
messages.messageBody:
Paul,
Thanks for the photo. By round, I was picturing a rounded maru mimi, not a round cross section. A round cross section is not typical for early Akasaka guards. Later when the Akasaka were copying Higo work, they used their thinner style of round section rim. I don't think I've seen this kind of rim on an Akasaka piece, but I can't say it's impossible. They did some unusual things.

I'm not sure about your piece. The looseness of the sukashi design reminds me of early Akasaka, although the bird at the top is pretty thick for them. The iron surface shows more "modulation" that is typical for Akasaka. It looks more like something from the Owari region. The seppa dai is not far from Akasaka shape. The guard reminds me a little of a third generation piece that I have:

http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/akasaka.htm (second guard down from the top).

Looking inside the sukashi openings do you see any signs of three layer construction?

Tough one... it's bugging me already. Some Akasaka style, but a lot that is not. And I don't know what the "is not" part is. Thinking out loud...

Jim



Thanks Jim,
Yes I did intend to attach a photo, sorry I might get the hang of technology in another 30 or 40 years. I have put the image in the album (I think) under paulb. Please take a look and let me know if its there and what you think.
many thanks
paul

Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:
Paul,
A thick, round rim is typical for early Akasaka guards. Later ones tend to be thinner. The early Akasaka really favored a very "high," rounded rim compared with other groups working at the same time.

Sometimes tekkotsu are seen in early examples. Senkotsu is more common, which is a sort of long linear bone that forms where the inner and outer plates are joined.

I'm not sure if you intended there to be an attached photo. The list doesn't permit attachments, but you can post images in the group photo album at:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/

Log in and click on the "Photos" link at the left. I can provide detailed instructions for anyone who would like to learn how to post photos. It's quite easy.

Jim

I understand that early Akasaka work was influenced by Owari tsuba, is this an example of this? or should I be looking in another direction.
All comments greatly appreciated.
